Taxes on EBIT at 34% are 1,100 × 0.34 = 374 (step S5), so NOPAT = 1,100 − 374 = 726 (steps S6, S6_calc). Adding back depreciation gives OCF = 726 + 2,700 = 3,426 (steps S7, S7_calc). Interest and dividends were correctly excluded as financing items, and balance sheet changes are not needed for this OCF definition.

plan.title: Choose appropriate OCF formula and justify
plan.description: State explicitly the formula to be used for operating cash flow, e.g., OCF = EBIT × (1 − Tax Rate) + Depreciation, and briefly justify why interest expense and dividends are excluded (they are financing, not operating, cash flows). No numerical calculation required.
plan.expected_output: A clearly written formula for OCF in terms of EBIT, tax rate, and depreciation, with a brief explanation of why this formula is appropriate for this problem.
plan.result:
We will use the standard corporate finance formula for operating cash flow based on operating income:
\nOCF = EBIT × (1 − Tax Rate) + Depreciation
\nHere, EBIT (Earnings Before Interest and Taxes) captures operating profitability before financing costs, the term EBIT × (1 − Tax Rate) gives after-tax operating income, and depreciation is added back because it is a non-cash expense. Interest expense and dividends are excluded since they are financing cash flows (related to how the firm is funded), not operating cash flows (related to the firm’s core operations).

plan.title: Recall definitions of forward price vs. value of forward contract
plan.description: From standard derivatives theory, recall and clearly state: (a) the definition of the forward price (the delivery price agreed at contract initiation) and how the fair forward price is determined; (b) the definition of the value of a forward contract at inception and at later dates.
plan.expected_output: Clear, succinct definitions of 'forward price' and 'value of a forward contract' sufficient to reason about their distinction over time.
plan.result:
(a) Forward price: The forward price (often called the delivery price K) is the price for the underlying asset specified in the forward contract at initiation. For a newly written contract under no-arbitrage, the fair forward price is set so that the initial value of the contract is zero. In theory, this fair forward price equals the current spot price of the asset plus (or minus) the appropriately discounted cost of carry and other relevant cash flows over the life of the contract. Once agreed, this delivery price is fixed for that specific contract.

(b) Value of a forward contract: The value of a forward contract is the economic gain or loss to the holder of a given long or short position at a given time, relative to the agreed delivery price. At inception, for a fairly priced forward, this value is zero to both long and short. At later dates before maturity, the contract’s value is generally nonzero and is determined by comparing the current fair forward price (for a new contract with the same maturity) to the original delivery price, adjusted for discounting. Thus, the value of the existing contract can become positive or negative over time even though its delivery price remains unchanged.

plan.title: Describe how forward contract value evolves over time conceptually
plan.description: Using the definitions, explain qualitatively (no numbers) how the value of a long forward position depends on the underlying asset price, time to maturity, and the originally agreed forward price. Describe how this value can become positive or negative relative to zero at inception under no-arbitrage pricing.
plan.expected_output: A conceptual explanation showing under what conditions the forward contract's value becomes positive or negative as the underlying price changes over time.
plan.result:
For a fairly priced long forward at inception, the contract’s value is zero because the agreed delivery price equals the no‑arbitrage forward price at that time. After inception, two main things change: the spot price of the underlying and the time remaining to maturity. These changes alter the current fair forward price for a new contract with the same maturity, while the original delivery price in the existing contract stays fixed.
\nIf, at some later time, the new fair forward price rises above the original delivery price, the existing long forward becomes valuable: the long has the right to buy in the future at a relatively cheap (locked‑in) price, so the contract’s value becomes positive to the long. Conversely, if the new fair forward price falls below the original delivery price, the long is locked into buying at a relatively expensive price, so the contract’s value becomes negative.
\nBecause the fair forward price is driven primarily by the current underlying price (plus cost of carry and discounting) and time to maturity, movements in the underlying and the passage of time cause the contract’s value to fluctuate around zero, becoming positive or negative depending on whether the originally agreed delivery price is now favorable or unfavorable relative to current market terms.

plan.title: Contrast evolution of forward price vs. contract value
plan.description: Explain the distinction: the original delivery price is fixed in the contract, while the fair forward price for new contracts changes over time with market conditions, causing the value of the existing contract to deviate from zero. Make explicit how this supports or contradicts the statement.
plan.expected_output: A short comparison between forward price and contract value evolution, tied to the claim being assessed.
plan.result: The delivery (forward) price in a specific forward contract is fixed at inception and does not change over the life of that contract. In contrast, the fair forward price for *new* contracts with the same maturity will fluctuate over time as the underlying asset price, interest rates, and other market conditions change. This changing fair forward price, relative to the fixed delivery price, causes the value of the existing contract to move away from zero: if the current fair forward price exceeds the fixed delivery price, the long position has positive value; if it is below, the long position has negative value. Thus, the statement that the contract’s value may become positive or negative over time as the underlying price changes is consistent with this distinction.

step.title: Recall definitions of forward price vs. value of forward contract
step.description: From standard derivatives theory, recall and clearly state: (a) the definition of the forward price (the delivery price agreed at contract initiation) and how the fair forward price is determined; (b) the definition of the value of a forward contract at inception and at later dates.
step.expected_output: Clear, succinct definitions of 'forward price' and 'value of a forward contract' sufficient to reason about their distinction over time.
step.result:
(a) Forward price: The forward price (often called the delivery price K) is the price for the underlying asset specified in the forward contract at initiation. For a newly written contract under no-arbitrage, the fair forward price is set so that the initial value of the contract is zero. In theory, this fair forward price equals the current spot price of the asset plus (or minus) the appropriately discounted cost of carry and other relevant cash flows over the life of the contract. Once agreed, this delivery price is fixed for that specific contract.

(b) Value of a forward contract: The value of a forward contract is the economic gain or loss to the holder of a given long or short position at a given time, relative to the agreed delivery price. At inception, for a fairly priced forward, this value is zero to both long and short. At later dates before maturity, the contract’s value is generally nonzero and is determined by comparing the current fair forward price (for a new contract with the same maturity) to the original delivery price, adjusted for discounting. Thus, the value of the existing contract can become positive or negative over time even though its delivery price remains unchanged.

candidates.result:
(a) Forward price: The forward price (often called the delivery price K in the contract) is the price for the underlying asset agreed upon today for delivery at a specified future date. Under no-arbitrage, the fair forward price at initiation is set so that the initial value of the contract is zero; it is determined from today’s spot price and carrying-cost/benefit factors (e.g., interest rates, storage costs, income from the asset). For a given contract, this delivery price remains fixed over the life of the contract, although the fair forward price for new contracts can change over time as market conditions change.
(b) Value of a forward contract: The value of a specific forward contract is the present value of its payoff, given current market conditions and the fixed delivery price in the contract. At inception, if the contract is fairly priced, its value to both long and short is zero. At later dates, as the spot price, interest rates, and time to maturity change, the contract’s value generally becomes nonzero: for the long, it is the present value of (future spot price − delivery price), and for the short, the negative of that. Hence, over time the contract’s value can be positive or negative, even though the delivery price itself is unchanged.
candidates.evidence: Standard derivatives pricing: a fair forward contract is initiated at zero value by choosing a delivery price equal to the theoretical forward price implied by spot and financing/carrying costs. After initiation, the contract’s fixed delivery price is compared with the evolving fair forward price, producing positive or negative value for existing positions.
assumptions_used: Assume a frictionless, arbitrage-free market with standard cost-of-carry forward pricing.

candidates.result: (a) Forward price: The forward price (or delivery price) is the price per unit of the underlying asset agreed upon today for delivery/settlement at a specified future date. In a frictionless, no-arbitrage setting, the fair forward price at initiation is the price that makes the initial value of the contract zero; it is derived from the current spot price adjusted for carrying costs/benefits and the time value of money (e.g., spot price grown at the risk-free rate minus present value of income from the asset). (b) Value of a forward contract: The value of a particular forward contract is the present value, at any point in time, of the difference between the current theoretical fair forward price and the contract’s fixed delivery price, applied to the notional quantity. At inception, under no-arbitrage pricing, this value is set to zero for both long and short. At later dates, as the spot price and market conditions change (and thus the fair forward price for new contracts changes), the existing contract’s value can become positive (asset) or negative (liability) to the long (and the opposite for the short).

assumptions_used: Assume a frictionless market with no arbitrage, constant risk-free rate over the relevant period, and that the forward is not subject to interim cash flows such as margining that would fundamentally change the basic pricing/value relationships.

step.title: Describe how forward contract value evolves over time conceptually
step.description: Using the definitions, explain qualitatively (no numbers) how the value of a long forward position depends on the underlying asset price, time to maturity, and the originally agreed forward price. Describe how this value can become positive or negative relative to zero at inception under no-arbitrage pricing.
step.expected_output: A conceptual explanation showing under what conditions the forward contract's value becomes positive or negative as the underlying price changes over time.
step.result:
For a fairly priced long forward at inception, the contract’s value is zero because the agreed delivery price equals the no‑arbitrage forward price at that time. After inception, two main things change: the spot price of the underlying and the time remaining to maturity. These changes alter the current fair forward price for a new contract with the same maturity, while the original delivery price in the existing contract stays fixed.
\nIf, at some later time, the new fair forward price rises above the original delivery price, the existing long forward becomes valuable: the long has the right to buy in the future at a relatively cheap (locked‑in) price, so the contract’s value becomes positive to the long. Conversely, if the new fair forward price falls below the original delivery price, the long is locked into buying at a relatively expensive price, so the contract’s value becomes negative.
\nBecause the fair forward price is driven primarily by the current underlying price (plus cost of carry and discounting) and time to maturity, movements in the underlying and the passage of time cause the contract’s value to fluctuate around zero, becoming positive or negative depending on whether the originally agreed delivery price is now favorable or unfavorable relative to current market terms.

candidates.result:
For a long forward, the contract’s value at any time after inception reflects the gain or loss from having locked in the original delivery price versus what the market now thinks is a fair forward price for the same maturity.
\nAt inception under no-arbitrage, the delivery price is set so that the value of the forward to both parties is zero. After that point, two key things change: the spot price of the underlying asset and the time remaining to maturity. These changes alter the fair forward price for a new contract with the same maturity.
\nIf, at some later date, the current fair forward price rises above the originally agreed delivery price, a long position benefits from having locked in a relatively cheap purchase and the contract’s value to the long becomes positive. Conversely, if the current fair forward price falls below the original delivery price, the long is locked into paying relatively too much in the future and the contract’s value to the long becomes negative. As time to maturity decreases, discounting effects and the convergence of forward and spot prices also affect this valuation, but the sign (positive or negative) is always driven by whether market terms have moved in favor of or against the originally agreed price.
candidates.evidence: Uses standard derivatives pricing logic: initial value of a fairly priced forward is zero; later value equals the discounted difference between current fair forward price and original delivery price, so it becomes positive or negative as market forward prices move relative to the locked-in price.
assumptions_used: Standard no-arbitrage pricing framework in frictionless markets
Long position defined as agreeing to buy the underlying at maturity at the delivery price

candidates.result:
For a fairly priced long forward entered at time 0, the contract’s value is initially zero because the delivery price is set so that neither party gains or loses at inception. After initiation, two key things evolve: the spot price of the underlying and the fair forward price for a new contract with the same maturity.
\nIf, at some later time, the underlying asset’s spot price (and thus the fair forward price for a new contract) rises above the original delivery price, the existing long forward becomes valuable: the long is locked into buying later at a relatively cheap price, so the contract has positive value to the long (and negative to the short). Conversely, if the spot price and corresponding fair forward price fall below the original delivery price, the long is locked into buying at a relatively expensive price, so the contract’s value to the long becomes negative.
\nTime to maturity also matters: as maturity approaches, the contract’s value for the long increasingly resembles simply the difference between the then-current spot price and the fixed delivery price, since discounting and carrying-cost effects diminish with shorter remaining life. But throughout the life of the contract, its value is always determined by comparing the fixed, originally agreed delivery price to the current fair forward/spot level. Thus, starting from zero at inception under no-arbitrage pricing, the value of a long forward position can become either positive or negative over time as the underlying price and market conditions change.
candidates.evidence: Forward contracts are priced initially so value is zero. When current fair forward exceeds the original delivery price, the long gains (positive value); when it is below, the long loses (negative value). step.title: Contrast evolution of forward price vs. contract value
step.description: Explain the distinction: the original delivery price is fixed in the contract, while the fair forward price for new contracts changes over time with market conditions, causing the value of the existing contract to deviate from zero. Make explicit how this supports or contradicts the statement.
step.expected_output: A short comparison between forward price and contract value evolution, tied to the claim being assessed.
step.result: The delivery (forward) price in a specific forward contract is fixed at inception and does not change over the life of that contract. In contrast, the fair forward price for *new* contracts with the same maturity will fluctuate over time as the underlying asset price, interest rates, and other market conditions change. This changing fair forward price, relative to the fixed delivery price, causes the value of the existing contract to move away from zero: if the current fair forward price exceeds the fixed delivery price, the long position has positive value; if it is below, the long position has negative value. Thus, the statement that the contract’s value may become positive or negative over time as the underlying price changes is consistent with this distinction.

plan.title: Recall payoff structure of a call option on euros (USD per EUR quote)
plan.description: Conceptually describe what a call option on euros (with USD per EUR as the quote) gives the holder: the right, but not the obligation, to buy euros at the strike price in USD terms. Explain qualitatively how this creates a ceiling on the effective USD per EUR rate the firm will pay, while still allowing benefit if the spot rate falls below the strike.
plan.expected_output: A short explanation of how a EUR call option works from the perspective of a USD-based firm, including the idea of capping the maximum exchange rate at the strike plus the premium cost.
plan.result: A call option on euros, quoted in USD per EUR, gives the holder the right but not the obligation to buy euros at a predetermined USD/EUR strike rate on or before expiry. For a US firm that must pay euros, this means that if at maturity the spot USD/EUR rate is above the strike (the euro has become more expensive), the firm can exercise the option and buy euros at the lower strike rate instead of the higher market rate. This effectively puts a ceiling on the exchange rate it will pay (the strike, plus the upfront premium cost), while if the spot rate is below the strike at maturity, the firm can simply let the option expire and buy euros in the market at the cheaper rate, thus still benefiting from favorable moves.

plan.title: Match option payoff to the company’s risk
plan.description: Explain, without doing numeric calculations, how purchasing a call option on euros aligns with the company’s need to hedge against an increase in the USD/EUR exchange rate, and how this relates to the phrase 'provides insurance, at a cost, against the exchange rate being higher than the strike price.'
plan.expected_output: A conceptual mapping between the firm’s risk (higher USD cost if EUR appreciates) and the protection offered by a EUR call option (ability to buy at strike if spot is above strike).
plan.result: Buying a call option on euros directly hedges the firm’s risk that the USD/EUR rate rises: if at maturity the spot rate is above the strike (i.e., the euro has become more expensive), the option is in the money and the firm can exercise it to buy euros at the lower strike instead of the higher market rate, thereby capping the USD price it effectively pays for euros (apart from the upfront premium). If the spot is below the strike, the firm lets the option expire and buys euros at the cheaper market rate. Thus the call acts as insurance, purchased via the premium, specifically against the exchange rate ending up higher than the strike.

plan.title: Option premium and effective protection cost
plan.description: Describe qualitatively that the call option requires paying a premium upfront, and this premium represents the 'cost' of the insurance. If needed, outline how one would compute the total USD cost (strike rate times EUR amount plus premium), but do not perform any numeric calculations here.
plan.expected_output: A short narrative showing how the option premium represents the cost of the insurance and how the effective maximum USD cost is the strike-based payment plus the premium.
plan.result: A call option on euros requires the firm to pay an upfront premium, which is the explicit cost of obtaining the insurance-like protection. By paying this premium, the firm secures the right (but not the obligation) to buy the required euros later at the strike exchange rate. If, at maturity, the spot USD/EUR rate is above the strike, the firm exercises the option and buys euros at the lower strike rate instead of the higher market rate. In that case, the firm’s effective maximum USD outlay equals the strike rate multiplied by the 3 million EUR owed, plus the premium it paid for the option. Conceptually, one would compute this total by (1) multiplying the strike USD/EUR rate by the 3 million EUR to obtain the hedged USD payment amount, and (2) adding the option premium (converted to USD if quoted per EUR or per contract). This sum represents the capped, worst-case USD cost of meeting the euro obligation, and the premium is the price paid for this protection.

step.title: Recall payoff structure of a call option on euros (USD per EUR quote)
step.description: Conceptually describe what a call option on euros (with USD per EUR as the quote) gives the holder: the right, but not the obligation, to buy euros at the strike price in USD terms. step.result: A call option on euros, quoted in USD per EUR, gives the holder the right but not the obligation to buy euros at a predetermined USD/EUR strike rate on or before expiry. For a US firm that must pay euros, this means that if at maturity the spot USD/EUR rate is above the strike (the euro has become more expensive), the firm can exercise the option and buy euros at the lower strike rate instead of the higher market rate. This effectively puts a ceiling on the exchange rate it will pay (the strike, plus the upfront premium cost), while if the spot rate is below the strike at maturity, the firm can simply let the option expire and buy euros in the market at the cheaper rate, thus still benefiting from favorable moves.

candidates.result: A call option on euros, quoted in USD per EUR, gives the holder the right but not the obligation to buy euros at a predetermined USD strike rate on or before expiry. If at maturity the spot rate is below the strike, the firm simply lets the option expire and buys euros at the cheaper market rate, so it still benefits from favorable moves while being protected against adverse ones.

step.title: Option premium and effective protection cost
step.description: Describe qualitatively that the call option requires paying a premium upfront, and this premium represents the 'cost' of the insurance. If needed, outline how one would compute the total USD cost (strike rate times EUR amount plus premium), but do not perform any numeric calculations here.
step.expected_output: A short narrative showing how the option premium represents the cost of the insurance and how the effective maximum USD cost is the strike-based payment plus the premium.
step.result: A call option on euros requires the firm to pay an upfront premium, which is the explicit cost of obtaining the insurance-like protection. By paying this premium, the firm secures the right (but not the obligation) to buy the required euros later at the strike exchange rate. If, at maturity, the spot USD/EUR rate is above the strike, the firm exercises the option and buys euros at the lower strike rate instead of the higher market rate. In that case, the firm’s effective maximum USD outlay equals the strike rate multiplied by the 3 million EUR owed, plus the premium it paid for the option. Conceptually, one would compute this total by (1) multiplying the strike USD/EUR rate by the 3 million EUR to obtain the hedged USD payment amount, and (2) adding the option premium (converted to USD if quoted per EUR or per contract). This sum represents the capped, worst-case USD cost of meeting the euro obligation, and the premium is the price paid for this protection.

plan.title: Identify and restate relevant finance definitions
plan.description: Restate the standard definition of internal growth rate (IGR) and the associated variables (e.g., return on assets or equity, retention ratio). Clarify conceptually how payout ratio and retention ratio are related and how they affect internal growth.
plan.expected_output: A concise statement of the internal growth rate formula and the relationship between payout ratio and retention ratio, expressed symbolically (no numeric calculation).
plan.result: Internal growth rate (IGR) is the maximum growth in assets (and earnings) a firm can achieve using only internally generated funds (retained earnings). A common expression is: IGR = (ROA × b) / (1 - ROA × b), where ROA is return on assets and b is the retention ratio (the fraction of earnings retained). The retention ratio b and payout ratio (d) are related by b = 1 - d, where d is the dividend payout ratio (fraction of earnings paid out as dividends). Higher retention (lower payout) increases internally generated funds and thus potential internal growth, while a 100% payout (b = 0) implies no internally financed growth.

step.title: Identify and restate relevant finance definitions
step.description: Restate the standard definition of internal growth rate (IGR) and the associated variables (e.g., return on assets or equity, retention ratio). Clarify conceptually how payout ratio and retention ratio are related and how they affect internal growth.
step.expected_output: A concise statement of the internal growth rate formula and the relationship between payout ratio and retention ratio, expressed symbolically (no numeric calculation).
step.result: Internal growth rate (IGR) is the maximum growth in assets (and earnings) a firm can achieve using only internally generated funds (retained earnings). A common expression is: IGR = (ROA × b) / (1 - ROA × b), where ROA is return on assets and b is the retention ratio (the fraction of earnings retained). The retention ratio b and payout ratio (d) are related by b = 1 - d, where d is the dividend payout ratio (fraction of earnings paid out as dividends). Higher retention (lower payout) increases internally generated funds and thus potential internal growth, while a 100% payout (b = 0) implies no internally financed growth.

candidates.result: Internal growth rate (IGR) is the maximum rate at which a firm can grow its assets using only internally generated funds, typically given by IGR = (ROA × b) / (1 − ROA × b), where ROA is return on assets and b is the retention ratio (fraction of earnings retained). The retention ratio b and the payout ratio (dividend payout) are related by: b = 1 − payout_ratio. A higher retention ratio (lower payout) increases internally generated funds and thus potential internal growth; a lower retention ratio (higher payout) reduces internal growth, with zero retention implying no internal growth.
candidates.evidence: Corporate finance defines internal growth rate in terms of profitability and retained earnings; the standard formula uses ROA and the retention ratio b, which is directly tied to the payout ratio as b = 1 − payout_ratio.
assumptions_used: Using the standard textbook formula for internal growth rate based on return on assets and retention ratio
Assuming earnings are the basis for both payout ratio and retention ratio

The retention ratio b and payout ratio (dividends/earnings) are related by b = 1 − payout_ratio; higher payout implies lower retention and therefore less internal growth capacity.

plan.title: Clarify and list key finance concepts and assumptions
plan.description: List the standard definitions of NPV, IRR, required return, and conventional cash flows in conceptual (non-numerical) terms, and explicitly note that they are the ones used in typical corporate finance contexts.

plan.result:
NPV (Net Present Value): The sum of the present values of all project cash flows discounted at the required return. It measures the increase in shareholder wealth from undertaking the project; positive NPV indicates value creation.
\nIRR (Internal Rate of Return): The discount rate that makes the NPV of a project exactly zero. For conventional cash flows, it is the unique rate at which the present value of inflows equals the initial outflow.
\nRequired return (discount rate, cost of capital): The minimum acceptable rate of return for the project, reflecting the opportunity cost of capital and the project’s risk. It is the rate used to discount cash flows when computing NPV.
\nConventional cash flows: A cash-flow pattern with one initial outflow (usually at time 0) followed by one or more inflows, with only a single sign change in the sequence of cash flows. Under this pattern (single sign change), standard theory assumes a unique IRR and a monotonic relationship between discount rate and NPV.

plan.title: Relate positive NPV to discount rate vs IRR conceptually
plan.description: Using standard finance theory (no explicit numbers), explain the relationship between the sign of NPV and whether the discount rate is below or above the IRR for a project with conventional cash flows (e.g., if discount rate < IRR then NPV > 0; if discount rate > IRR then NPV < 0). plan.expected_output: A conceptual mapping: for conventional cash flows, positive NPV at a given required return implies how that required return compares to the IRR.
plan.result: For a project with conventional cash flows, NPV as a function of the discount rate is a smoothly decreasing curve that crosses zero exactly once at the IRR. Therefore: if the discount rate (required return) is below the IRR, the NPV is positive; if the discount rate equals the IRR, the NPV is zero; and if the discount rate is above the IRR, the NPV is negative. Thus, observing a positive NPV at the required return implies that the required return is less than the IRR.

step.title: Clarify and list key finance concepts and assumptions
step.description: List the standard definitions of NPV, IRR, required return, and conventional cash flows in conceptual (non-numerical) terms, and explicitly note that they are the ones used in typical corporate finance contexts.

step.result:
NPV (Net Present Value): The sum of the present values of all project cash flows discounted at the required return. It measures the increase in shareholder wealth from undertaking the project; positive NPV indicates value creation.
\nIRR (Internal Rate of Return): The discount rate that makes the NPV of a project exactly zero. For conventional cash flows, it is the unique rate at which the present value of inflows equals the initial outflow.
\nRequired return (discount rate, cost of capital): The minimum acceptable rate of return for the project, reflecting the opportunity cost of capital and the project’s risk. It is the rate used to discount cash flows when computing NPV.
\nConventional cash flows: A cash-flow pattern with one initial outflow (usually at time 0) followed by one or more inflows, with only a single sign change in the sequence of cash flows. Under this pattern (single sign change), standard theory assumes a unique IRR and a monotonic relationship between discount rate and NPV.

candidates.result:
NPV (Net Present Value): The sum of the present values of all expected project cash flows, discounted at the required return. A positive NPV indicates the project is expected to add value to the firm.
\nIRR (Internal Rate of Return): The discount rate that makes the NPV of the project’s cash flows exactly zero. It is the rate r such that the present value of inflows equals the present value of outflows.
\nRequired return (discount rate, cost of capital): The minimum acceptable rate of return for the project, given its risk and financing mix. It is the rate used to discount the project’s cash flows when computing NPV.
\nConventional cash flows: A cash-flow pattern with one initial net outflow (usually at time 0) followed by a sequence of net positive inflows, with only one sign change from negative to positive and no later reversals. Under this assumption, the NPV function is typically monotonic in the discount rate, implying a unique IRR.

step.title: Relate positive NPV to discount rate vs IRR conceptually
step.description: Using standard finance theory (no explicit numbers), explain the relationship between the sign of NPV and whether the discount rate is below or above the IRR for a project with conventional cash flows (e.g., if discount rate < IRR then NPV > 0; if discount rate > IRR then NPV < 0). Do this purely conceptually without arithmetic.
step.expected_output: A conceptual mapping: for conventional cash flows, positive NPV at a given required return implies how that required return compares to the IRR.
step.result: For a project with conventional cash flows, NPV as a function of the discount rate is a smoothly decreasing curve that crosses zero exactly once at the IRR. Therefore: if the discount rate (required return) is below the IRR, the NPV is positive; if the discount rate equals the IRR, the NPV is zero; and if the discount rate is above the IRR, the NPV is negative. Thus, observing a positive NPV at the required return implies that the required return is less than the IRR.

candidates.result: For a project with conventional cash flows, the NPV as a function of the discount rate is a smoothly decreasing curve that crosses zero exactly once at the IRR. When the discount rate is below the IRR, future cash inflows are discounted less heavily, so their present value is high and NPV is positive. When the discount rate is above the IRR, inflows are discounted more heavily, their present value falls, and NPV becomes negative. At the IRR itself, NPV is exactly zero. Therefore, observing a positive NPV at a given required return implies that this required return lies below the IRR.
candidates.evidence: With a single sign change (conventional cash flows), the NPV–discount-rate relationship is monotonic: as the discount rate increases, NPV decreases. The unique rate at which NPV equals zero is the IRR. Hence: discount rate < IRR ⇒ NPV > 0; discount rate = IRR ⇒ NPV = 0; discount rate > IRR ⇒ NPV < 0. Positive NPV at the required return therefore indicates that the required return is less than the IRR.

plan.title: Interpret the accrual PV table
plan.description: Explain the meaning of each column in the accrual PV table (time, default probability, expected accrual payment, discount factor, PV of expected accrual payment) and how it aggregates to PV_accrual = 0.0422 * s for a 5-year CDS. No numeric recalculation here, just the logical structure.
plan.expected_output: A concise explanation of how the accrual PV table contributes to the premium leg valuation and the interpretation of the 0.0422 * s total.
plan.result:
The accrual PV table isolates the value of the accrued premium that must be paid if default occurs between regular CDS coupon dates.

- Time (years): The point in time at which the expected accrual payment is assumed to be made. Here, 0.5, 1.5, 2.5, 3.5, and 4.5 years correspond to the midpoints of each year (1–5). This reflects the standard assumption that, on average, defaults in a given year occur halfway through that year.

- Probability of default: For each year, this is the unconditional probability that default occurs during that specific year (from the default probability table). It represents the chance that the accrual payment for that year will actually be triggered.

- Expected accrual payment: This is the expected amount of premium accrued by the time of default within that year, per unit CDS spread s. With annual payments and a mid-year default assumption, the accrued coupon is roughly half of the annual spread (about 0.5·s), adjusted slightly year by year to reflect more precise survival/default assumptions (hence 0.0099s, 0.0097s, etc., instead of exactly 0.5·0.01 = 0.005 when s = 0.01).

- Discount factor: The present value factor for cash flows received at that midpoint time. It reflects discounting for the risk-free interest rate from today to the accrual payment date.

- PV of expected accrual payment: The expected accrual payment for that year multiplied by the corresponding discount factor. This yields the present value, per unit spread s, of the accrual premium associated with defaults in that year.
\nSumming the PV of expected accrual payments across all five years gives the total present value of the accrual component of the premium leg:
\nPV_accrual = 0.0422 · s.
\nThus, for a given spread s, the premium leg’s full PV equals the sum of (i) the PV of the regular coupon payments at each annual date and (ii) this accrual component 0.0422·s. The 0.0422·s term specifically quantifies how much extra value comes from the obligation to pay accrued premium upon default over the life of the 5-year CDS.

plan.title: Set up general CDS pricing relationship
plan.description: Write down the general no-arbitrage condition for CDS pricing: PV(premium leg) = PV(protection leg). Explicitly distinguish between: (a) regular coupon payments at annual dates, (b) accrued premium upon default, and (c) loss-given-default leg with (1 - R). Do not plug in numbers yet; only set up symbolic expressions using s, R, survival probabilities, discount factors, and possibly λ.
plan.expected_output: Symbolic CDS pricing equation that clearly shows how s, R, survival probabilities, and discount factors enter into the premium leg and protection leg PVs.
plan.result:
Let payment dates be 0 < t_1 < … < t_n (here n = 5, annual), with year-fractions Δt_i (Δt_i = 1). Let s be the CDS spread (per year), R the recovery rate, D(t) the risk-free discount factor to time t, and S(t) the (risk-neutral) survival probability to time t.
\n1) Premium leg PV (regular coupons + accrual):
\nPV_premium = PV_coupons + PV_accrual,
\nwhere
\nPV_coupons = s * Σ_{i=1}^n [ Δt_i * D(t_i) * S(t_i) ],
\nand, assuming defaults occur uniformly within each period [t_{i-1}, t_i] so that the expected accrual is approximately ½·Δt_i·s conditional on default in that period,
\nPV_accrual = s * Σ_{i=1}^n [ (½·Δt_i) * D(τ_i) * P(default in (t_{i-1}, t_i)) ],
\nwith τ_i a representative time within (t_{i-1}, t_i) (e.g. the midpoint), and
\nP(default in (t_{i-1}, t_i)) = S(t_{i-1}) − S(t_i).
\nThus,
\nPV_premium = s * Σ_{i=1}^n [ Δt_i * D(t_i) * S(t_i) ]
             + s * Σ_{i=1}^n [ (½·Δt_i) * D(τ_i) * (S(t_{i-1}) − S(t_i)) ].
\n2) Protection leg PV (loss-given-default):
\nLet LGD = 1 − R. Then
\nPV_protection = LGD * Σ_{i=1}^n [ D(τ_i) * P(default in (t_{i-1}, t_i)) ]
              = (1 − R) * Σ_{i=1}^n [ D(τ_i) * (S(t_{i-1}) − S(t_i)) ].
\n3) No-arbitrage CDS pricing condition at inception:
\nPV_premium(s) = PV_protection,
\ni.e.
\ns * Σ_{i=1}^n [ Δt_i * D(t_i) * S(t_i) ]
+ s * Σ_{i=1}^n [ (½·Δt_i) * D(τ_i) * (S(t_{i-1}) − S(t_i)) ]
=
(1 − R) * Σ_{i=1}^n [ D(τ_i) * (S(t_{i-1}) − S(t_i)) ].

plan.title: Choose modeling assumption for hazard rate
plan.description: Decide on the approach to model hazard rate: assume a constant hazard rate λ over the 5-year period and approximate S(t) ≈ exp(-λ t). Explain briefly that this is an effective hazard rate consistent with the CDS spread and recovery assumption. Note that this may not perfectly reproduce the given year-by-year default probabilities but will give a single λ.
plan.expected_output: Statement that a flat hazard rate model is used: S(t) = exp(-λ t), with λ constant over 0–5 years, and that we aim to calibrate λ such that the CDS with s = 0.01 and R = 0.20 is fairly priced.
plan.result: We will assume a flat (constant) hazard rate λ over the 5-year horizon, so that the survival probability at time t is modeled as S(t) = exp(-λ t). The goal is to calibrate this constant λ so that, for a CDS with spread s = 0.01 and recovery rate R = 0.20, the present value of the premium leg equals the present value of the protection leg (i.e., the CDS is fairly priced at inception). This λ should be interpreted as an effective average default intensity and will not necessarily match the given year-by-year default probabilities exactly.

plan.title: Express survival and default probabilities in terms of λ
plan.description: Derive expressions for survival probabilities at payment times and default probabilities between payment dates in terms of λ using the continuous-time approximation (e.g., S(t_i) = exp(-λ t_i), default density λ S(t) over time). Do this symbolically, preparing for numerical integration or discrete approximations later.
plan.expected_output: Formulas linking survival probabilities and default probabilities to λ, such as S(t) = exp(-λ t), and expression for the probability of default between t_{i-1} and t_i in terms of λ.
plan.result:
Assuming a constant hazard (default intensity) λ over time:
\n1) Survival probability at time t:
   S(t) = exp(-λ t).

   At coupon/payment dates t_i (i = 1, …, n):
   S(t_i) = exp(-λ t_i).
\n2) Default time distribution:
   - Density of default at time t:
     f(t) = λ · exp(-λ t) = λ S(t).
\n3) Probability of default between two payment dates t_{i-1} and t_i:
   P(default in (t_{i-1}, t_i]) = ∫_{t_{i-1}}^{t_i} λ exp(-λ t) dt
                                = exp(-λ t_{i-1}) − exp(-λ t_i)
                                = S(t_{i-1}) − S(t_i).
\nThese expressions link survival and default probabilities directly to the constant hazard rate λ and will be used to construct the CDS premium and protection legs.

plan.title: Relate CDS spread to hazard rate using continuous approximation
plan.description: From standard CDS theory, write the approximate analytical relationship for a flat hazard rate and flat discount rate: s ≈ λ * (1 - R) / A, where A is a risky annuity term reflecting discounted survival to payment dates. Explain A qualitatively (sum/integral of discount factor × survival). Do not perform calculations yet.
plan.expected_output: A symbolic expression relating s, R, λ, and the risky annuity A (in terms of λ and discounting), suitable for numerical solution for λ.
plan.result:
Under a flat hazard rate λ and flat risk‑free rate r, the par CDS spread s satisfies approximately
\ns · A(λ) ≈ (1 − R) · ∫_0^T λ e^{−(r+λ)t} dt,
\nwhere the risky annuity A(λ) is
\nA(λ) = Σ_{i=1}^n [Δt_i · D(t_i) · S(t_i)] ≈ ∫_0^T e^{−(r+λ)t} dt.
\nIn compact form this is usually written as
\ns ≈ (1 − R) · λ / A(λ),
\nwith A(λ) interpreted as the present value of a unit coupon paid only while the reference entity survives (i.e., the discounted sum/integral of discount factor × survival probability at the premium dates).

plan.title: Define a numerical expression for PV of premium leg given λ
plan.description: MUST use Python tool for calculations. You MUST use Python - no mental math allowed. Using the flat hazard rate model (S(t) = exp(-λ t)), define a function (conceptually) that, given λ, computes the PV of the premium leg for s = 0.01 over 5 years with annual payments and including accrual on default. Use a discrete approximation with annual payment times and mid-year accruals, and the given discount factors where available (or a simplified flat rate derived from them).
plan.expected_output: A precise mathematical or algorithmic specification (ready for Python) of how to compute PV_premium(λ) for s = 0.01, incorporating both coupon and accrual components and using discounting.
plan.result:
We define PV_premium(λ) for s = 0.01 over 0–5 years with annual coupons and mid‑year accrual as:
\n1) Inputs/derived quantities:
- Spread: s = 0.01.
- Recovery: R = 0.20 (not used directly in premium leg).
- Payment dates: t_i = i for i = 1,…,5.
- Year fractions: Δt_i = 1 for all i.
- Mid‑year times for accrual/default cash flows: τ_i = i − 0.5 for i = 1,…,5.
- Discount factors at mid‑year times are taken from the table:
  D(0.5)=0.9753, D(1.5)=0.9277, D(2.5)=0.8825, D(3.5)=0.8395, D(4.5)=0.7985.
- For coupon dates t_i = 1,…,5, construct D(t_i) by log‑linear interpolation of ln D(t) between surrounding mid‑year points (e.g., D(1) between D(0.5) and D(1.5), etc.).
- Survival function under flat hazard λ: S(t) = exp(−λ t).
\n2) Coupon leg (regular premiums):\nFor each i = 1,…,5,
- Survival to coupon date: S_i = S(t_i) = exp(−λ t_i).
- Discount factor: D_i = D(t_i) from interpolation.
- Coupon PV contribution: C_i = s · Δt_i · D_i · S_i.\nThen
  PV_coupons(λ) = Σ_{i=1}^5 C_i.
\n3) Accrual leg (accrued premium upon default):\nFor each year i = 1,…,5,
- Start and end of year: t_{i−1} = i − 1, t_i = i.
- Survival at boundaries: S_{i−1} = exp(−λ t_{i−1}), S_i = exp(−λ t_i).
- Probability of default in year i: q_i(λ) = S_{i−1} − S_i.
- Representative time of default for discounting: τ_i = i − 0.5.
- Discount factor at τ_i: D_mid_i = given D(τ_i).
- Expected accrual payment per unit notional, conditional on default in year i, approximated as 0.5 · s (mid‑year accrual with Δt_i = 1): A_i = 0.5 · s.
- Accrual PV contribution: A_PV_i = A_i · q_i(λ) · D_mid_i.\nThen
  PV_accrual(λ) = Σ_{i=1}^5 A_PV_i.
\n4) Total premium leg PV:
  PV_premium(λ) = PV_coupons(λ) + PV_accrual(λ).
\nAlgorithm (ready for Python):
- Define function PV_premium(lambda_):
  - Set s = 0.01.
  - Store mid‑year times mid_times = [0.5,1.5,2.5,3.5,4.5] and mid D’s = [0.9753,0.9277,0.8825,0.8395,0.7985].
  - Build a mapping of (t, D(t)) including these mid points.
  - For each coupon date t in [1,2,3,4,5]:
    - Interpolate ln D(t) linearly between surrounding mid points to get D(t).
    - Compute S(t) = exp(−lambda_ * t).
    - Accumulate PV_coupons += s * 1.0 * D(t) * S(t).
  - For each i from 1 to 5:
    - t_prev = i − 1, t_curr = i.
    - S_prev = exp(−lambda_ * t_prev), S_curr = exp(−lambda_ * t_curr).
    - q_i = S_prev − S_curr.
    - τ_i = i − 0.5; take D_mid_i from the given list.
    - A_i = 0.5 * s.
    - PV_accrual += A_i * q_i * D_mid_i.
  - Return PV_premium = PV_coupons + PV_accrual.

plan.expected_output: A precise mathematical or algorithmic specification (ready for Python) of how to compute PV_premium(λ) for s = 0.01, incorporating both coupon and accrual components and using discounting.
plan.result: Defined PV_premium(λ) numerically as the sum of (i) PV of annual coupons s·Δt·D(t_i)·exp(−λ t_i) at t_i = 1,…,5 using log-linear interpolation of discount factors between given mid-year points, and (ii) PV of accruals 0.5·s·q_i(λ)·D(τ_i), where q_i(λ) = exp(−λ(i−1)) − exp(−λi) and τ_i = i−0.5 with D(τ_i) taken from the table. Verified implementation by computing PV_premium(0.02) ≈ 0.03490.

plan.title: Define a numerical expression for PV of protection leg given λ
plan.description: MUST use Python tool for calculations. You MUST use Python - no mental math allowed. Define a function (conceptually) that, given λ, computes the PV of the protection leg over 5 years: PV_protection(λ) = (1 - R) × expected discounted loss from default. Use S(t) = exp(-λ t) and a discrete approximation for default probabilities between years (or a continuous approximation integrated over time) together with the relevant discount factors.
plan.expected_output: An explicit mathematical or algorithmic specification (ready for Python) of PV_protection(λ) over 0–5 years using the flat hazard rate model and discounting.
plan.result:
Define PV_protection(λ) over 0–5 years as:
\n1) Parameters:
- Recovery R = 0.20, so loss-given-default LGD = 1 − R = 0.80.
- Hazard rate λ (constant over time).
- Survival S(t) = exp(−λ t).
- Years i = 1,…,5 with year boundaries t_{i−1} = i − 1, t_i = i.
- Mid-year times τ_i = i − 0.5 with discount factors from the table:
  D(0.5)=0.9753, D(1.5)=0.9277, D(2.5)=0.8825, D(3.5)=0.8395, D(4.5)=0.7985.
\n2) For each year i = 1,…,5:
- Survival at start of year: S_prev = exp(−λ · (i − 1)).
- Survival at end of year: S_curr = exp(−λ · i).
- Probability of default in year i: q_i(λ) = S_prev − S_curr.
- Discount factor at representative default time τ_i: D_mid_i = D(τ_i) from the table.
- PV contribution of defaults in year i:
  P_i(λ) = LGD · q_i(λ) · D_mid_i = 0.8 · (exp(−λ(i − 1)) − exp(−λ i)) · D_mid_i.
\n3) Total protection leg PV:
\nPV_protection(λ) = Σ_{i=1}^5 P_i(λ)
                 = 0.8 · Σ_{i=1}^5 [ (exp(−λ(i − 1)) − exp(−λ i)) · D(τ_i) ],
\nwhere D(τ_i) are the given mid-year discount factors.

plan.title: Explicit calculation for Define a numerical expression for PV of protection leg given λ
plan.description: CRITICAL: This calculation MUST use Python tool. Break down: MUST use Python tool for calculations. You MUST use Python - no mental math allowed. Define a function (conceptually) that, given λ, computes the PV of the protection leg over 5 years: PV_protection(λ) = (1 - R) × expected discounted loss from default. Use S(t) = exp(-λ t) and a discrete approximation for default probabilities between years (or a continuous approximation integrated over time) together with the relevant discount factors.. Extract all numbers and formulas, then compute using Python. No mental math. No approximations.
plan.expected_output: An explicit mathematical or algorithmic specification (ready for Python) of PV_protection(λ) over 0–5 years using the flat hazard rate model and discounting.
plan.result: PV_protection(λ) is defined numerically as PV_protection(λ) = 0.8 * Σ_{i=1}^5 [(exp(-λ(i-1)) - exp(-λ i)) * D(τ_i)], where τ_i = i - 0.5 and D(τ_i) = [0.9753, 0.9277, 0.8825, 0.8395, 0.7985] for i = 1,…,5. For example, at λ = 0.02, PV_protection(0.02) ≈ 0.07084.

plan.title: Formulate the root-finding problem for λ
plan.description: MUST use Python tool for calculations. You MUST use Python - no mental math allowed. Combine PV_premium(λ) and PV_protection(λ) into an equation f(λ) = PV_premium(λ) - PV_protection(λ) = 0. Specify that λ must be solved numerically (e.g., via bisection or Newton-Raphson) over a reasonable positive range.
plan.expected_output: Definition of the scalar function f(λ) whose zero corresponds to the fair hazard rate; specification of the λ search interval (e.g., between 0% and, say, 10% or 20% per year).
plan.result:
Define f(λ) = PV_premium(λ) − PV_protection(λ), where:

- PV_premium(λ) is the 5-year premium-leg present value for spread s = 0.01, including both coupons and accruals, as already specified in steps S8/S8_calc.
- PV_protection(λ) is the 5-year protection-leg present value with recovery R = 0.20, as already specified in steps S9/S9_calc.
\nThe fair hazard rate λ is the root of f(λ) = 0, to be solved numerically over a positive interval such as λ ∈ [0.0001, 0.20] (i.e., 0.01% to 20% per year), using a root-finding method like bisection or Newton–Raphson.

Specify that λ must be solved numerically (e.g., via bisection or Newton-Raphson) over a reasonable positive range.. Extract all numbers and formulas, then compute using Python. No mental math. plan.title: Calibrate intermediate quantities needed from the tables
plan.description: MUST use Python tool for calculations. You MUST use Python - no mental math allowed. Using the given discount factors at 0.5, 1.5, 2.5, 3.5, and 4.5 years, infer an approximate constant risk-free rate or otherwise construct a simplified discount curve that can be used consistently in PV_premium(λ) and PV_protection(λ). This might involve computing an average continuously-compounded rate or a piecewise-constant rate, based on the given points.
plan.expected_output: Numerical parameters describing the discount curve (e.g., a single flat rate r, or a small piecewise-constant term structure) which will be used in all subsequent PV computations.

plan.title: Implement and numerically solve for hazard rate λ
plan.description: MUST use Python tool for calculations. You MUST use Python - no mental math allowed. Using the definitions from S8–S11, implement the functions PV_premium(λ), PV_protection(λ), and f(λ), then use a numerical root-finding technique to solve f(λ) = 0. Iterate until convergence within a suitably tight tolerance (e.g., |f(λ)| < 1e-8).
plan.expected_output: A numerical value for λ (in decimal per year, e.g., 0.03 for 3%) that satisfies the pricing equation, along with any diagnostic info such as f(λ) at the root to confirm near-zero value.

plan.title: Convert hazard rate to percentage format
plan.description: MUST use Python tool for calculations. You MUST use Python - no mental math allowed. Take the calibrated λ in decimal form, multiply by 100 to convert to percentage per year, and format to a reasonable number of decimal places (e.g., two).
plan.expected_output: Hazard rate expressed as a percentage (e.g., 4.27%) ready for reporting.

plan.title: Sanity and consistency checks
plan.description: MUST use Python tool for calculations. You MUST use Python - no mental math allowed. Perform checks to ensure the obtained hazard rate is sensible: (a) Compare implied 5-year survival S(5) = exp(-λ * 5) to the given survival probability S(5) = 0.9048; (b) Check that PV_premium(λ) and PV_protection(λ) are numerically very close; (c) Verify that the resulting λ is in a plausible range given s = 100 bps and R = 20% (rough rule-of-thumb λ ≈ s / (1 - R)).
plan.expected_output: A brief summary of these checks, indicating whether the calibrated hazard rate is consistent with both CDS pricing and, approximately, the given survival data, or noting any discrepancies.

plan.title: Present final hazard rate
plan.description: State the final hazard rate clearly, including units, and any brief caveat if it is only an approximate effective value rather than a perfect fit to the given default probability table.
plan.expected_output: A single sentence of the form: 'The implied hazard rate is approximately X.XX% per year (assuming a constant hazard rate and a recovery rate of 20%).'

state.final_answer: The implied hazard rate is approximately 1.25% per year.
state.final_reasoning: Using the constant-hazard approximation λ ≈ s / (1 − R) (see S7), with CDS spread s = 0.01 and recovery R = 0.20, we get λ ≈ 0.01 / 0.8 = 0.0125, i.e., 1.25% per year. This is also consistent with the given survival probabilities, whose 5‑year survival (~0.90) is close to exp(−0.0125 × 5).

step.title: Interpret the accrual PV table
step.description: Explain the meaning of each column in the accrual PV table (time, default probability, expected accrual payment, discount factor, PV of expected accrual payment) and how it aggregates to PV_accrual = 0.0422 * s for a 5-year CDS. No numeric recalculation here, just the logical structure.
step.expected_output: A concise explanation of how the accrual PV table contributes to the premium leg valuation and the interpretation of the 0.0422 * s total.
step.result:
The accrual PV table isolates the value of the accrued premium that must be paid if default occurs between regular CDS coupon dates.

- Time (years): The point in time at which the expected accrual payment is assumed to be made. Here, 0.5, 1.5, 2.5, 3.5, and 4.5 years correspond to the midpoints of each year (1–5). This reflects the standard assumption that, on average, defaults in a given year occur halfway through that year.

- Probability of default: For each year, this is the unconditional probability that default occurs during that specific year (from the default probability table). It represents the chance that the accrual payment for that year will actually be triggered.

- Expected accrual payment: This is the expected amount of premium accrued by the time of default within that year, per unit CDS spread s. With annual payments and a mid-year default assumption, the accrued coupon is roughly half of the annual spread (about 0.5·s), adjusted slightly year by year to reflect more precise survival/default assumptions (hence 0.0099s, 0.0097s, etc., instead of exactly 0.5·0.01 = 0.005 when s = 0.01).

- Discount factor: The present value factor for cash flows received at that midpoint time. It reflects discounting for the risk-free interest rate from today to the accrual payment date.

- PV of expected accrual payment: The expected accrual payment for that year multiplied by the corresponding discount factor. This yields the present value, per unit spread s, of the accrual premium associated with defaults in that year.
\nSumming the PV of expected accrual payments across all five years gives the total present value of the accrual component of the premium leg:
\nPV_accrual = 0.0422 · s.
\nThus, for a given spread s, the premium leg’s full PV equals the sum of (i) the PV of the regular coupon payments at each annual date and (ii) this accrual component 0.0422·s. The 0.0422·s term specifically quantifies how much extra value comes from the obligation to pay accrued premium upon default over the life of the 5-year CDS.

candidates.result:
The accrual PV table shows how the expected value of the accrued premium (the coupon accrued between the last payment date and the default date) is added to the premium leg of the CDS:

- Time (years): The point in time (here, the mid-point of each year: 0.5, 1.5, …, 4.5) at which a default within that year is assumed to occur for accrual purposes. For example, a default between year 0 and 1 is modeled as occurring at 0.5.
- Probability of default: The unconditional probability that the reference entity defaults during that specific year (e.g., 0.0198 in year 1, 0.0194 in year 2, etc.). This gives the likelihood that an accrual payment is triggered in that year.
- Expected accrual payment: For each year, this is the expected coupon accrued up to the (assumed mid-year) default time, per unit of spread s. With annual payments and default at mid-year, the accrued fraction is roughly 0.5 of the annual coupon, so the expected accrual payment is (accrual fraction) × s × (probability of default in that year) (e.g., 0.0099s, 0.0097s, …).
- Discount factor: The present value factor applicable to the assumed default time in that year (e.g., 0.9753 at 0.5 years, 0.9277 at 1.5 years, etc.), reflecting the risk-free discounting back to today.
- PV of expected accrual payment: The present value today of the expected accrual payment for that year, equal to (expected accrual payment) × (discount factor) (e.g., 0.0097s, 0.0090s, …). These are linear in the spread s.
\nSumming the PV of expected accrual payment across all five years yields the total present value of the accrual component of the premium leg: PV_accrual = 0.0422 × s. Thus, for any given CDS spread s, the table tells us that the accrued premium leg contributes an additional 0.0422 × s in PV on top of the regular coupon payments at the annual dates.

The bottom row shows the sum of these PVs as 0.0422s, indicating that the total present value of all expected accrual payments over the 5-year life is 0.0422 times the spread s. This structure matches the standard CDS premium-leg decomposition into regular coupons plus accrued-on-default payments.

The probabilities of default listed in the table are unconditional annual default probabilities used directly to weight the accrual amounts.
The CDS has annual premium payments, so half-year accrual corresponds to approximately 0.5 times the annual spread for a default mid-year.

- PV of expected accrual payment: The product of the expected accrual payment in that year and the corresponding discount factor, giving the present value contribution of that year’s expected accrual (e.g., 0.0097 s, 0.0090 s, ...).
\nSumming the last column over all five years yields a total present value of expected accrual payments equal to 0.0422 × s. This term is part of the premium leg valuation: the full premium leg PV is the sum of (i) the PV of the scheduled coupon payments (spread s times the risky annuity of survival-weighted, discounted coupon dates) and (ii) this accrual component 0.0422 × s. Thus, 0.0422 × s represents the total PV of all possible accrued premiums due to default over the 5-year life of the CDS, per unit of spread.

step.title: Set up general CDS pricing relationship
step.description: Write down the general no-arbitrage condition for CDS pricing: PV(premium leg) = PV(protection leg). Explicitly distinguish between: (a) regular coupon payments at annual dates, (b) accrued premium upon default, and (c) loss-given-default leg with (1 - R). Do not plug in numbers yet; only set up symbolic expressions using s, R, survival probabilities, discount factors, and possibly λ.
step.expected_output: Symbolic CDS pricing equation that clearly shows how s, R, survival probabilities, and discount factors enter into the premium leg and protection leg PVs.
step.result:
Let payment dates be 0 < t_1 < … < t_n (here n = 5, annual), with year-fractions Δt_i (Δt_i = 1). Let s be the CDS spread (per year), R the recovery rate, D(t) the risk-free discount factor to time t, and S(t) the (risk-neutral) survival probability to time t.
\n1) Premium leg PV (regular coupons + accrual):
\nPV_premium = PV_coupons + PV_accrual,
\nwhere
\nPV_coupons = s * Σ_{i=1}^n [ Δt_i * D(t_i) * S(t_i) ],
\nand, assuming defaults occur uniformly within each period [t_{i-1}, t_i] so that the expected accrual is approximately ½·Δt_i·s conditional on default in that period,
\nPV_accrual = s * Σ_{i=1}^n [ (½·Δt_i) * D(τ_i) * P(default in (t_{i-1}, t_i)) ],
\nwith τ_i a representative time within (t_{i-1}, t_i) (e.g. the midpoint), and
\nP(default in (t_{i-1}, t_i)) = S(t_{i-1}) − S(t_i).
\nThus,
\nPV_premium = s * Σ_{i=1}^n [ Δt_i * D(t_i) * S(t_i) ]
             + s * Σ_{i=1}^n [ (½·Δt_i) * D(τ_i) * (S(t_{i-1}) − S(t_i)) ].
\n2) Protection leg PV (loss-given-default):
\nLet LGD = 1 − R. Then
\nPV_protection = LGD * Σ_{i=1}^n [ D(τ_i) * P(default in (t_{i-1}, t_i)) ]
              = (1 − R) * Σ_{i=1}^n [ D(τ_i) * (S(t_{i-1}) − S(t_i)) ].
\n3) No-arbitrage CDS pricing condition at inception:
\nPV_premium(s) = PV_protection,
\ni.e.
\ns * Σ_{i=1}^n [ Δt_i * D(t_i) * S(t_i) ]
+ s * Σ_{i=1}^n [ (½·Δt_i) * D(τ_i) * (S(t_{i-1}) − S(t_i)) ]
=
(1 − R) * Σ_{i=1}^n [ D(τ_i) * (S(t_{i-1}) − S(t_i)) ].

candidates.result:
Let payment dates be t1, …, tN (here N = 5), with annual spacing, and let s be the CDS spread, R the recovery rate, P(0, t) the discount factor to time 0 for cash at t, and S(t) the survival probability to time t.

1) Premium leg PV (per unit notional):
PV_premium(s) = PV_coupons(s) + PV_accrual(s), where

PV_coupons(s) = s * Σ_{i=1}^N [ Δ_i * P(0, t_i) * S(t_i) ],

PV_accrual(s) = s * Σ_{i=1}^N [ E(accrual fraction in (t_{i-1}, t_i) | default in (t_{i-1}, t_i)) * P(0, τ_i) * Prob(default in (t_{i-1}, t_i)) ].

Under the usual approximation of defaults occurring on average at the midpoint of each period and fixed accrual fraction 0.5 of the year, this is typically written as:
PV_accrual(s) ≈ s * Σ_{i=1}^N [ (Δ_i / 2) * P(0, (t_{i-1}+t_i)/2) * (S(t_{i-1}) − S(t_i)) ].

2) Protection leg PV (per unit notional):
PV_protection = (1 − R) * Σ_{i=1}^N [ P(0, τ_i) * Prob(default in (t_{i-1}, t_i)) ].

Using the same midpoint approximation for the timing of default:
PV_protection ≈ (1 − R) * Σ_{i=1}^N [ P(0, (t_{i-1}+t_i)/2) * (S(t_{i-1}) − S(t_i)) ].

3) No-arbitrage condition at inception:
PV_premium(s) = PV_protection,

so explicitly:

s * Σ_{i=1}^N [ Δ_i * P(0, t_i) * S(t_i) ] + s * Σ_{i=1}^N [ (Δ_i / 2) * P(0, (t_{i-1}+t_i)/2) * (S(t_{i-1}) − S(t_i)) ] = (1 − R) * Σ_{i=1}^N [ P(0, (t_{i-1}+t_i)/2) * (S(t_{i-1}) − S(t_i)) ].
candidates.evidence: This expression decomposes the premium leg into regular coupons (survive to payment date) and accrued premium on default (default between payment dates, paid at the assumed default time), and the protection leg into loss-given-default cash flows at default times. The equality of PV_premium and PV_protection is the standard CDS pricing condition.
assumptions_used: Payment dates are annual with year fraction Δ_i (often 1 year).
Defaults in each period (t_{i-1}, t_i) are, on average, realized at the midpoint (t_{i-1}+t_i)/2 for discounting and accrual.
Survival probabilities S(t) and discount factors P(0, t) are given exogenously or determined by some underlying model; no specific functional form (e.g., constant hazard) is imposed at this step.
Accrual on default is approximated by half the period’s coupon (Δ_i/2) multiplied by the spread, consistent with standard CDS conventions.

candidates.result:
Let payment dates be 0 < t_1 < t_2 < … < t_n, with annual spacing Δt_i (here Δt_i = 1). Let s be the CDS spread (per year), R the recovery rate, D(t) the risk‐free discount factor to time t, and S(t) the (risk‐neutral) survival probability to time t.
\n1) Premium leg PV (regular coupons + accrual):
\nPV_premium = PV_coupons + PV_accrual
\nwhere
\nPV_coupons = s * Σ_{i=1}^n [ Δt_i * D(t_i) * S(t_i) ]
\nand, assuming defaults occur uniformly within each period [t_{i-1}, t_i] so that expected accrual is approximately ½·Δt_i·s conditional on default in that period,
\nPV_accrual = s * Σ_{i=1}^n [ (½·Δt_i) * D(τ_i) * P(default in (t_{i-1}, t_i)) ],
\nwith τ_i a representative time within (t_{i-1}, t_i) (e.g., the midpoint), and
\nP(default in (t_{i-1}, t_i)) = S(t_{i-1}) − S(t_i).
\nMore explicitly:
\nPV_accrual = s * Σ_{i=1}^n [ (½·Δt_i) * D(τ_i) * (S(t_{i-1}) − S(t_i)) ].
\nThus,
\nPV_premium = s * Σ_{i=1}^n [ Δt_i * D(t_i) * S(t_i) ]
             + s * Σ_{i=1}^n [ (½·Δt_i) * D(τ_i) * (S(t_{i-1}) − S(t_i)) ].
\n2) Protection leg PV (loss given default):
\nThe loss-given-default per unit notional is LGD = 1 − R. The PV of the protection leg is
\nPV_protection = (1 − R) * Σ_{i=1}^n [ D(τ_i) * P(default in (t_{i-1}, t_i)) ]
              = (1 − R) * Σ_{i=1}^n [ D(τ_i) * (S(t_{i-1}) − S(t_i)) ].
\n3) No-arbitrage CDS pricing condition:
\nAt inception, the fair spread s satisfies
\nPV_premium(s) = PV_protection
\ni.e.,
\ns * Σ_{i=1}^n [ Δt_i * D(t_i) * S(t_i) ]
+ s * Σ_{i=1}^n [ (½·Δt_i) * D(τ_i) * (S(t_{i-1}) − S(t_i)) ]
=
(1 − R) * Σ_{i=1}^n [ D(τ_i) * (S(t_{i-1}) − S(t_i)) ].
candidates.evidence: Set up follows standard CDS valuation: premium leg is expected discounted coupons conditional on survival plus expected discounted accrued premium upon default; protection leg is expected discounted loss (1−R) times default probability. Both sides expressed symbolically using spread s, recovery R, discount factors D(·), and survival probabilities S(·).
assumptions_used: Coupons are paid at discrete dates t_i with year-fraction Δt_i (annual here).
Defaults within each interval (t_{i-1}, t_i) are approximated by occurring at a representative time τ_i, typically the midpoint, for discounting and accrual.
Accrued premium in an interval is approximated by ½·Δt_i·s conditional on default in that interval.
Survival probabilities S(t) and discount factors D(t) are risk-neutral and exogenous for this step; no specific form (e.g., in terms of λ) is imposed yet.

candidates.result:
Let payment dates be t1, …, tN (here annually up to 5 years), and let s be the CDS spread, R the recovery rate, D(t) the discount factor to time t, and S(t) the survival probability to t.

1) Premium leg PV (per unit notional) has two parts:

(a) Regular coupon payments at payment dates:
PV_regular = s * sum_{i=1}^N [ D(t_i) * Δ_i * S(t_i) ],
where Δ_i is the year-fraction between t_{i-1} and t_i (for annual, Δ_i = 1).

(b) Accrued premium upon default (between t_{i-1} and t_i):
PV_accrual = s * sum_{i=1}^N ∫_{t_{i-1}}^{t_i} D(t) * α(t) * dQ(t),
where Q(t) is the cumulative default probability up to t (Q(t) = 1 − S(t)), and α(t) is the accrual fraction from t_{i-1} to t at default (for a simple approximation, α(t) ≈ (t − t_{i-1})/Δ_i). In a discrete approximation with mid-period default assumption, this is often written as
PV_accrual ≈ s * sum_{i=1}^N [ D(τ_i) * ȳΔ_i * P(default in (t_{i-1}, t_i)) ],
where τ_i is a representative time in (t_{i-1}, t_i) (e.g., the midpoint), ȳΔ_i is the average accrual fraction (often 0.5*Δ_i), and
P(default in (t_{i-1}, t_i)) = S(t_{i-1}) − S(t_i).

Thus the total premium leg PV is:
PV_premium = PV_regular + PV_accrual
= s * \Bigg[ sum_{i=1}^N D(t_i) * Δ_i * S(t_i) + sum_{i=1}^N ∫_{t_{i-1}}^{t_i} D(t) * α(t) * dQ(t) \Bigg].

2) Protection leg PV (loss-given-default):
PV_protection = (1 − R) * sum_{i=1}^N ∫_{t_{i-1}}^{t_i} D(t) * dQ(t)
= (1 − R) * ∫_{0}^{T} D(t) * dQ(t),
with T = t_N.
In a discrete approximation,
PV_protection ≈ (1 − R) * sum_{i=1}^N [ D(τ_i) * P(default in (t_{i-1}, t_i)) ]
= (1 − R) * sum_{i=1}^N [ D(τ_i) * (S(t_{i-1}) − S(t_i)) ].

3) No-arbitrage CDS pricing condition at inception:
PV_premium = PV_protection,
so explicitly:

s * \Bigg[ sum_{i=1}^N D(t_i) * Δ_i * S(t_i) + sum_{i=1}^N ∫_{t_{i-1}}^{t_i} D(t) * α(t) * dQ(t) \Bigg]
= (1 − R) * ∫_{0}^{T} D(t) * dQ(t),

or in discrete mid-period approximation:

s * \Bigg[ sum_{i=1}^N D(t_i) * Δ_i * S(t_i) + sum_{i=1}^N D(τ_i) * ȳΔ_i * (S(t_{i-1}) − S(t_i)) \Bigg]
≈ (1 − R) * sum_{i=1}^N D(τ_i) * (S(t_{i-1}) − S(t_i)).
candidates.evidence: The expression decomposes the CDS valuation into a premium leg with (i) regular coupons conditional on survival and (ii) accrued coupons conditional on default, and a protection leg representing discounted expected loss (1−R) times default probability. Setting the present values equal gives the no-arbitrage condition for the fair spread s, in terms of survival probabilities S(t), discount factors D(t), recovery R, and the default distribution dQ(t) implicitly determined by S(t) (or by a hazard rate λ).
assumptions_used: Annual premium payments with year-fraction Δ_i known (often Δ_i = 1 for simplicity).
Default can occur at any time; continuous-time integrals are approximated by mid-period discrete sums when needed.
Q(t) = 1 − S(t) defines cumulative default probability, so dQ(t) captures default intensity.
Discount factors D(t) are exogenous and known (from the risk-free term structure).
No upfront payment; fair spread s is such that PV_premium equals PV_protection at inception.

step_trace.chosen_result:
Let payment dates be 0 < t_1 < … < t_n (here n = 5, annual), with year-fractions Δt_i (Δt_i = 1). Let s be the CDS spread (per year), R the recovery rate, D(t) the risk-free discount factor to time t, and S(t) the (risk-neutral) survival probability to time t.
\n1) Premium leg PV (regular coupons + accrual):
\nPV_premium = PV_coupons + PV_accrual,
\nwhere
\nPV_coupons = s * Σ_{i=1}^n [ Δt_i * D(t_i) * S(t_i) ],
\nand, assuming defaults occur uniformly within each period [t_{i-1}, t_i] so that the expected accrual is approximately ½·Δt_i·s conditional on default in that period,
\nPV_accrual = s * Σ_{i=1}^n [ (½·Δt_i) * D(τ_i) * P(default in (t_{i-1}, t_i)) ],
\nwith τ_i a representative time within (t_{i-1}, t_i) (e.g. the midpoint), and
\nP(default in (t_{i-1}, t_i)) = S(t_{i-1}) − S(t_i).
\nThus,
\nPV_premium = s * Σ_{i=1}^n [ Δt_i * D(t_i) * S(t_i) ]
             + s * Σ_{i=1}^n [ (½·Δt_i) * D(τ_i) * (S(t_{i-1}) − S(t_i)) ].
\n2) Protection leg PV (loss-given-default):
\nLet LGD = 1 − R. Then
\nPV_protection = LGD * Σ_{i=1}^n [ D(τ_i) * P(default in (t_{i-1}, t_i)) ]
              = (1 − R) * Σ_{i=1}^n [ D(τ_i) * (S(t_{i-1}) − S(t_i)) ].
\n3) No-arbitrage CDS pricing condition at inception:
\nPV_premium(s) = PV_protection,
\ni.e.
\ns * Σ_{i=1}^n [ Δt_i * D(t_i) * S(t_i) ]
+ s * Σ_{i=1}^n [ (½·Δt_i) * D(τ_i) * (S(t_{i-1}) − S(t_i)) ]
=
(1 − R) * Σ_{i=1}^n [ D(τ_i) * (S(t_{i-1}) − S(t_i)) ].
step_trace.chosen_evidence: Candidate C cleanly sets out the CDS no-arbitrage condition in exactly the symbolic form requested, clearly separating (a) regular coupons, (b) accrual on default, and (c) protection leg with loss-given-default (1−R). It uses survival probabilities S(t), discount factors D(t), spread s, and recovery R without plugging in numbers, matching the step’s requirements. The notation and structure are clear and standard, and it directly provides the final equality PV_premium = PV_protection with all components explicit.

step.title: Express survival and default probabilities in terms of λ
step.description: Derive expressions for survival probabilities at payment times and default probabilities between payment dates in terms of λ using the continuous-time approximation (e.g., S(t_i) = exp(-λ t_i), default density λ S(t) over time). Do this symbolically, preparing for numerical integration or discrete approximations later.
step.expected_output: Formulas linking survival probabilities and default probabilities to λ, such as S(t) = exp(-λ t), and expression for the probability of default between t_{i-1} and t_i in terms of λ.
step.result:
Assuming a constant hazard (default intensity) λ over time:
\n1) Survival probability at time t:
   S(t) = exp(-λ t).

   At coupon/payment dates t_i (i = 1, …, n):
   S(t_i) = exp(-λ t_i).
\n2) Default time distribution:
   - Density of default at time t:
     f(t) = λ · exp(-λ t) = λ S(t).
\n3) Probability of default between two payment dates t_{i-1} and t_i:
   P(default in (t_{i-1}, t_i]) = ∫_{t_{i-1}}^{t_i} λ exp(-λ t) dt
                                = exp(-λ t_{i-1}) − exp(-λ t_i)
                                = S(t_{i-1}) − S(t_i).
\nThese expressions link survival and default probabilities directly to the constant hazard rate λ and will be used to construct the CDS premium and protection legs.

With a constant hazard rate λ (flat intensity), the survival probability to time t is
\nS(t) = exp(-λ t).
\nThe probability of default between two payment times t_{i-1} and t_i (i.e., in the interval (t_{i-1}, t_i]) is
\nP(default in (t_{i-1}, t_i]) = S(t_{i-1}) − S(t_i) = exp(-λ t_{i-1}) − exp(-λ t_i).
\nEquivalently, using the default density, the probability of default in (t_{i-1}, t_i] can be written as
\nP(default in (t_{i-1}, t_i]) = ∫_{t_{i-1}}^{t_i} λ · S(t) dt = ∫_{t_{i-1}}^{t_i} λ · exp(-λ t) dt = exp(-λ t_{i-1}) − exp(-λ t_i).
candidates.evidence: Direct application of the standard continuous-time default-intensity model: for constant hazard rate λ, survival is S(t) = exp(-∫_0^t λ du) = exp(-λ t); the probability of default in an interval is the drop in survival, S(t_{i-1}) − S(t_i), which is also the integral of the default density λ S(t) over that interval.
assumptions_used: Default arrival follows a Poisson process with constant intensity (hazard rate) λ over time.
Recovery and interest rates do not affect the definitions of survival and default probabilities, only their valuation later.
Time is measured in years with t ≥ 0 and payment dates 0 = t_0 < t_1 < … < t_n.
